This should lead to a diversity of node operators of different sizes, with different risk appetites, and distributed geographically.

I do think the future will include a plethora of nodes being operated by companies that span many different industries. Not just exchanges. Media companies, e-commerce stores, and any other type of company you can think of will have dedicated personnel for managing a LN node.

Oh, one last thing. This experience is making me bullish on the future of decentralization if the Lightning Network. @dj_seeds and I have become obsessed with developing ways to optimize our LN node for this use case.

I am eager to see a number of different monetization models pop up as time goes on. 

A sincere thank you to anyone who paid for content this week. It means a lot that people are willing to spend some sats on my words.

The future is bright!

Either way, there‚Äôs no denying that we are in a Golden Era of reworking how things are monetized on the Web. And it‚Äôs all enabled by the LNP/BP stack. This is what Web 3.0 truly looks like IMO. Don‚Äôt let anyone tell you that bitcoin is boring. They don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on.

While I do love the value-4-value model I do want to experiment with this pay-to-view model as I think it is a truly novel way to monetize content and people seem willing to pay. This creates much more certainty for someone putting time into their content.
I hope this is the beginning of a shift in the world of written content monetization on the web. Peer-to-peer payments that enable a seamless browsing experience.

The thought of a one-click experience gets me very excited because that will be a undeniable step function improvement when compared to the paywalls thrown up by @wsj, @business, and others. It‚Äôs 10x better for UX and 100x better for user privacy.
This can be made even easier over time by integrating LSAT as @roasbeef points out.

The thing I‚Äôm most proud of is the amount of comments that expressed how easy and seamless the LN payment flow was. As you can see from the demo in the first tweet, you click a button, get asked to open a LN wallet, pay the invoice, and have the content released immediately.
We had over 500 paywalls paid for immediately via the Lightning Network for the two Bents that went out on Thursday and Friday. Honestly, this is way more than I was expecting.

Hoping to have the subscribe flow UX buttoned up and fully integrated with @BtcpayServer in the next month or two. 

Now to the data.
For those who want to pay in sats, that‚Äôll have to be done via the site for now. This does come with the benefit of not having to connect to give up your info to @stripe.

Second, we are still working to hack @BtcpayServer into the @ghost paid subscriber flow, so for now those who want to pay to get the paywalled Bents sent straight to their inboxes they‚Äôll have to pay with fiat. We hope to change that soon.

First, to ensure that paid members get the paid content sent to their inbox while giving unpaid members a preview of the rag we‚Äôve had to get creative with some @ghost editor loopholes. This increases the chances of human error which is why we had broken links. That‚Äôs on me.

.@dj_seeds has been working hard to fully integrate @BtcpayServer into our @ghost instance and we finally felt comfortable rolling it out.

Even though things seems very dark (because they are), there are many things to be optimistic about at this current juncture. We're going to win and it's going to be pretty awesome.

The lagging effects of the Regime's influence over the global economy will continue to be felt throughout this decade and some things may continue to get worse for a time, but the rebuilding process is already well under way.

Similarly with healthcare, it has become abundantly clear that Big Pharma cares much more about profit than it does about making people healthy. The fuckery around COVID-19 has led many to focus on preventative care and healthier living. An incredible development.

Likewise, as energy reliability deteriorates even further in large states and cities I expect people to begin demanding better energy infrastructure. It is unacceptable that we have experienced energy curtailment in NY, CA and TX in the 21st century.

As supply chain issues continue to get worse and it gets harder than it already is to get things that could be bought and shipped with ease just a couple of years ago I expect individuals to get creative to begin solving these problems and bring manufacturing on-shore.

Obviously, we see this drive to action already happening with Bitcoin.

@branninmcbee @rubenfalk @nic__carter Turning a process that can be 30% efficient into one that is close to 100% isn't marginal. Methane leak via flaring is a big problem the O&G industry is actively looking to solve.

@branninmcbee @rubenfalk @nic__carter Flares aren't 100% efficient at combusting CH4. Many are actually very inefficient in windy conditions and if they aren't serviced properly over time. Running it through an EPA certified generator guarantees close to 100% combustion.

@branninmcbee @rubenfalk @nic__carter It seems that you are the one who is misinterpreting things as is evidenced by the fact that the OP in this thread is quoting me saying that the mining reduces CH4 and not CO2. The benefits aren't being overstated either, they are material at the producer level.

@Truthcoin My argument is things *are* being invented that should aid the fee market.

An extremely underappreciated aspect of bitcoin is its increasing utility as collateral.

h/t @fiatminimalist 

https://t.co/w0Usg5otRA

Don't let the haters try to convince you otherwise. These people don't have any vision and lack an understanding of economics. 

Particularly, Jevons Paradox. 

Number go up. Bitcoin fixes this. Get over it.

When you combine all of this, it is incredibly stupid to claim with any sense of authority that Bitcoin's long-term security is at risk.

The number of things one can do with a UTXO is increasing at an incredible rate. This utility will drive demand, and create a fee market.

As oil and gas companies continue to wake up and realize they can use all of the FREE gas they are currently wasting on their fields to mine bitcoin, this will severely reduce the price at which your average miner can mine profitably. An externality that many are blind to atm.
We haven't even touched on the future dynamics of mining, which provides the long-term security that people are so worried about.

On top of this, it would be incredibly naive to think that these will be the only second layer technologies that come to market over time. One needs to factor in solutions that haven't even been thought up yet into their long-term Bitcoin security models.

As these particular second layer solutions mature and become more useful to bitcoin users, this will also stoke demand for UTXOs that can be locked up and leveraged in more unique ways, driving up fees.

We're only talking about technological innovations at the protocol level at this point. We haven't even mentioned second layer tech like the Lightning Network and Liquid, which also increase the utility of UTXOs.

As the Bitcoin protocol continues to advance technologically (SegWit, Schnorr, Taproot, OpCTV, DLCs, assumeutxo, Erlay, etc.), individuals will be able to do more creative things with their UTXOs, which should stoke demand for UTXOs, driving up fees.

This is pure demand for block space driven by speculation. 

Only one aspect that will contribute to the fee market and Bitcoin's long-term security as the block subsidy falls.

This is where Jevons Paradox comes into play.

Bitcoin isn't on top of the public's mind like it was in the Fall/Winter of 2017.

If number continues to go up like it has consistently done for the last 11 years, this should stoke activity in the fee market as more people are dragged into Bitcoin's gravitational pull. https://t.co/zAf73uQTz5

Yes, Bitcoin's fee market may be paltry at the moment due to better use of the blockchain as individuals and businesses learn how to use block space more efficiently. I will concede this. 

However, one needs to look to where the puck is going.
Individuals who clamor on about Bitcoin's dwindling block subsidy and claim that Bitcoin's long-term security is in question lack vision and an understanding of Jevons Paradox.

This is a first iteration of this experiment, so bear with us as we work out the kinks along the way and DM me with any feedback you have.

We hope the Bitcoin Namespace develops into a unique place for bitcoiners & those looking to learn more about Bitcoin to interact, converse and share information.

We also want it to be a place where quality Bitcoin content gets better visibility than other publishing sites.

The Bitcoin Namespace is one of the first channels to try this experiment out.

You can now create a profile on @Digg, follow the Bitcoin Namespace, and submit links to Bitcoin content that you think would be beneficial for Digg's audience.

Join us.

Some of you may already know, but I've been helping curate a Bitcoin channel at @Digg for a few months.

These efforts are about to turn up as Digg experiments with a new Medium + Reddit content production and curation model.

@TheStalwart The combination of Bitcoin's hardness, immutability, and distributed nature, among other things, is what makes it a unique asset.

Unpopular opinion: While extremely compelling, I do not think it is wise to take the S2F pricing model as gospel. 

It opens up another "fast and free transactions" like blunder if it doesn't play out.

Expectations management is important when teaching others about Bitcoin.

Threaded today's …Éent because it seems to have struck a chord.
Complacency kills. Wake the fuck up.

Seize your sovereignty, educate people about the tools they can use to do the same, and hopefully, through action, we'll be able to get to a point where attacks on our liberties from the State are ephemeral. If we do not act, we may never be truly free.

As we can see, the State does not like when you call out its wrongdoings or attempt to curb its power. Money is at the root of their power and we would be naive to believe they won't be threatened by Bitcoin too. 
 
 All the more reason to stop being complacent and act.
‚Ä¶describing these actions as anything other than journalism, the act of bringing truth to light), we Bitcoiners better believe we won't be immune to similar treatment in the future.

Attempting to insert itself into every action and transaction on Earth. 
 
 Bitcoin is certainly not a panacea, but it is a step in the right direction. And if the US government is willing to rip a man out of a foreign embassy for a bit of old fashioned journalism (miss me with‚Ä¶
It swings a bit of leverage back to the individual who has felt helpless as he has watched the encroachment of an evil system creep further and further into his everyday life.

The grubby politicians are not going to do it for us. They are captured by the system. 
 
 This is why I Bitcoin, freaks. It presents an opportunity to opt into a system completely separated from the corrupt system we currently live under.

We are a society standing by passively as we become slaves to a system that is out to divide and exploit us. It is time that we realize that we may not be able to change the world into our liking until we understand that we must do it ourselves.
Stuck in a perpetual cycle of fighting amongst ourselves while the political, banking, and media elite sit on the sidelines eating popcorn, basking in the glory of the plebs tearing themselves apart.
All the while, we allow these evil people to divide us using victimhood culture and fear-mongering with obscure boogeymen only the State can save us from.

To think that these people actually want to help the citizenry is laughable. 
 
 Every election cycle we are forced to choose between the Red team or the Blue team that are both out to bend us over and rape and pillage our pockets and civil liberties.

If you've been paying attention long enough, you'll come to believe that it's because we currently live in a system that we have ZERO power over. We are fed a bullshit trough of "options" every four years of rich politicians, most of whom run for office to stroke their egos.

Why is it that we have quick spurts of shock and awe; utterly flabberghasted by the notion that our governments act nefariously behind our backs, but are completely unable to change the way things are?

‚Ä¶the DNC undermining the Democratic primary in 2016. All in the name of "Freedom and Liberty". These are but a few examples that come to mind at the moment. 
 
 Despite these truths being brought to life, nothing has changed. Why is this?

‚Ä¶in Falluja, murdering a group of journalists and children who were mistaken for insurgents, bombing a wedding party using heat-seeking missiles dropped from miles above the Earth, indiscriminately spying on every citizen they can using an inescapable digital panopticon, and‚Ä¶

Because of people like Snowden and Manning and organizations like WikiLeaks we plebs have been able to pull the curtain on the Wizard of Oz and find out the truth of what really happens in our world. Over the years we have learned of our government using white phosphorous‚Ä¶
The memory of these feelings made me realize how little has changed since all of these horrible atrocities against human lives and civil liberties were revealed to the public.
I can vividly remember the visceral feelings of injustice and anger that rushed through me during the wake of these revelations.
Back when they were dropping groundbreaking revelations like the Manning files and helping Edward Snowden escape the country as he was revealing the extent to which we are all being spied on.
Waking up to this news produced flashbacks to years ago when Wikileaks was a more prominent figure in the news.

As most of you freaks are probably aware of by now, Julian Assange has been dragged out of the Ecuadorian embassy in London and is en route to the "Land of the Free" to face charges for helping Chelsea Manning break into a classified computer system.

"... the goal of any navy should be to control of the commons. Control of the commons means controlling commerce, and the gears of commerce move the world.

Satoshi built all of humanity a weapon to take that power for ourselves."

Wake up, freaks. Evil is winning.

 Beyond in-game purchases, users could even battle each other and wager bets on the outcome with the winner taking the satoshis home with him.

@BR_Robin People are spending massive amounts of money on unique skins, dance moves, and avatars in games. This will not change any time soon. If microtransactions via the LN proves to be a better UX for all parties involved and catches on, this will drive massive demand for BTC.

@BR_Robin ‚Ä¶enabling in-game economies that were previously impossible due to the inability to leverage microtransactions in such a seamless fashion. This makes me bullish from so many angles. Gaming is one of the biggest and fastest growing industries in the world at the moment.

@BR_Robin Imagine a world where users hold their own balances on their own nodes or in a browser extension that acts as a hot wallet for small amounts of BTC (<$20) and run from free game to free game using the LN to pay for needed tools and accessibility, funding game developers and‚Ä¶
@BR_Robin The ability to spend fractions of a penny on in-game goods or accessibility is revolutionary. It would be impossible to do this via traditional payment rails like Visa or Mastercard.

@BR_Robin This may not seem that significant to you now, but this is an incredible development that may incite a feedback loop that could change the dynamic of in-game commerce, drive demand for BTC, and act as a liquidity provider and talent draw for the LN.
@BR_Robin A little more than half a penny to unlock the door.

@BR_Robin In the demo, the player is incited to pay a 150 satoshi fee to open a door. The player then uses their LN wallet to pay the fee instantly, opening the door within seconds. 
 
 To help you conceptualize this, here's what 150 satoshis is worth at the time of this writing, $0.00532.

@BR_Robin This demo of an in-game payment made via the Lightning Network (LN) piqued my interest over the weekend and I think it's something your freaks should definitely check out as it presents a clear use case that could drive demand for bitcoin in the future.

KYC is a gaping security hole. 

It makes us less safe than we would be if we were simply allowed to conduct commerce without the eye of Sauron watching us. 

The collection of personal data on the servers of companies creates massive honeypots for hackers. We need to do better.

However the economic design of the transaction market fails to generate high enough fees. A simple model suggests that ultimately, it could take nearly a year, or 50,000 blocks, before a payment could be considered ‚Äúfinal‚Äù.

For example, in Bitcoin and many of the clones that have ‚Äúforked‚Äù from it, the next time block rewards will halve is in 2020. Whenever block rewards decrease, the security of payments decreases and transaction fees become more important to guarantee the finality of payments.

... As a result, liquidity is set to deteriorate substantially in years to come. The backdrop is that the bulk of miners‚Äô current income consists of block rewards. But block rewards are being phased out...

"The key takeaway of this paper concerns the interaction of these two limitations: proof-of-work can only achieve payment security if mining income is high, but the transaction market cannot generate an adequate level of income...
Biggest takeaway from this paper; the BIS doesn‚Äôt think a fee market will develop to sustain Bitcoin‚Äôs security.
Our society is on the brink. The statistics are similar here in the US. We need to get back to a world run on honest money.

@matt_odell Pushing innovation and usability further, to a point which this technology can be used in a stress-free way by the average man. Who knows if we'll ever get there, but it is very encouraging to see these products coming to market and iterating so quickly. Onward!

@matt_odell The competition is beautiful and it is extremely beneficial for Bitcoin and the future of financial sovereignty. 
 
 Hopefully, more entrepreneurs see the paths paved by these pioneers and decide to jump in the fray.

@matt_odell The proliferation of wallets like Wasabi, Samourai, and JoinMarket and hardware products like Casa, Nodl, and Dojo is lighting a fire under the asses of the people working on these products as they race to provide the market with the best, most user-friendly experience.

@matt_odell As has been uttered in this rag many times in the past, I believe we are seeing UX improve at a steady pace across the industry due to all the different software and hardware projects competing to provide users with privacy tools.

@matt_odell On top of this, he explains how to relay transactions outside of Internet Service Providers. 
 
 If anything, this guide points out the glaring need for improved privacy in Bitcoin and a better UX flow to make it easier for users to utilize these services.

@matt_odell minty does an extremely thorough job, walking readers through ways in which they can attain bitcoins for cash, explaining the different privacy-focused wallets, and the underlying tech that works to ensure your UTXOs aren't easily traceable across the blockchain.

@matt_odell As you can see from the above screenshot, our friend mintycosta does not give a darn about your political views or your thoughts on KYC/AML, he is only interested in equipping his readers with the best practices one should use when attempting to ensure their financial privacy.
